title: Boswelliana
snippet: She tohl him, ' Sir, you shall just have them for a guinea a week, you furnishing coal and candle.' Baldie, with much emotion, cried out, ' But I tell you, woman, I have no coal and candle.' " "Boswell said of Miss Stewart, of Blackhall,* 'that more brilliant beauties came armed with darts and attacked men as foes, but Miss Stewart carried no weapons of destruction, and treated with them as with allies.' " " Lord Eglintoune said to Boswell, whose lively imagination formed many schemes, but whose indolence hindered him from executing them, ' Jamie, you have a light head, but a heavy a ,' " " Lord Eglintoune said to Boswell, who was maintaining that by habit he would acquire the power of application to business, ' Application must be an original vigour of mind. The arm of any blacksmith may become so strong by habit that he may gain his bread ; but if he has not natural strength he will never make excellent work.' " " The Spaniards are a noble people ; at least, their gentlemen have great souls.

title: Journal of a tour through the Highlands of Scotland during the summer of MDCCCXXIX.
author: Botfield, Beriah
snippet: At Banchory Ternan, a sunny and rural spot, whitened cottages are scattered among the larch plantations on the northern bank of the stream, on the opposite side of which, a magnificent amphitheatre of shady groves, and stately forests, embosom the beautiful domain of Blackball, the en trance to which appeared before us, as soon as we had crossed the rapid and cataractons water of Feuch- This stream rises in lOochnabane, whose pro minent nodosity was from hence singularly conspi cuous. The lodge of Blackhall is a Grecian screen, on the central arch of which stands a goat, sub scribed with the motto of the noble house of Rus sell, " Che sara sara," though we were told a Mr. Campbell resided in that apparently sweet spot. Immediately beyond the lodge, we crossed the Dee, and entered Banchory Ternan, which we found en circled by every grand component of picturesque scenery.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: There were pre- Bent, Middleton, commissioner, Glencairn, chancellor, Duke Hamilton, Montrose, Morton, Eglinton, Lithgow, Callend.-ir. Ncwburgh, Sinclair, Sir James Lockhart of Lee, and Blackhall ; and the report was, being conveened at Glasgow, there vm never a man among them but he was drunk at the time, except only Lee. But when they were sett, the commissioner propounds the case and the bishop's overture, which all approve except the Lord Lee.

title: Marabou Stork Nightmares
author: Welsh, Irvine
snippet: We usually just got as far as the fuckin beach, before getting fed up and going hame. Occasionally we'd walk to snobby bits like Barnton, Cramond or Blackhall. The polis would always come around and make us go hame, though.

title: Works of R. L. Stevenson. (Edinburgh edition.) [Edited by Sidney Colvin.]
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: Suppose he pawned his watch ? But no, on Christmas Day—this was Christmas Day !—the pawn-shop would be closed. Suppose he went to the public-house close by at Blackhall, and offered the watch, which was worth ten pounds, in payment for a meal of bread and cheese ? The incongruity was too remarkable ; the good folks would either put him to the door, or only let him in to send for the police. He turned his pockets out one after another; some San Francisco tram-car checks, one cigar, no lights, the passkey to his father's house, a pocket-handkerchief,

title: The Testament of Gideon Mack
author: Robertson, James
snippet: Jenny was doing a secretarial course there, but she didn't seem to care about it very much. Her family – her mother, father and a younger sister – had moved from the south of England when she was thirteen, and she lived with them out at Blackhall, o

title: Boswelliana
snippet: The Parterre began to make a noise like the firing of cannon. One * Miss Margaret Stewart, eldest daughter of Sir Michael Stewart, Bart., of Blackhall, married in 1764 Sir William Maxwell, Bart., of Springkell. She had a younger sister, Eleanora, who died unmarried.

title: The Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott. (Supplementary volume: containing notes, historical and illustrative, by the author, glossary, etc.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: "Ay! and that's e'en true, cummer," said the lame hag, propping herself with a crutch, which supported the shortness of her left leg, " for I mind when the father of this Master of Ravenswood that is now standing before us, sticked young Blackhall with his whinger, for a wrang word said ower their wine, or brandy, or what not—he gaed in as light as a lark, and he came out wi' his feet foremost. I was at the winding of the corpse; and when the bluid was washed off, he was a bonnie bouk of man's body."
